Idiom (Fijian): E dua na buka levu e sa kama tiko
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A major issue or crisis is happening beneath the surface.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: There is a serious problem going on.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from the Fijian relationship to fire as a communal symbol of both warmth and destruction.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Fijian): /e ndu.a na βu.ka le.vu e sa ka.ma ˈti.ko/
First Example Sentence: Era kaya na lewe ni koro ni e dua na buka levu e sa kama tiko ena nodra vale ni bose.
Second Example Sentence: E vaka ga ni sa dua na buka levu e sa kama tiko ena matanitu qo.
Third Example Sentence: E tukuna o Mere ni sa dua na buka levu e sa kama tiko ena nodra vuvale.

Idiom (Fijian): Sa taura na mata ni ika
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To take the lead or gain attention in a situation.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To be the center of attention.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to fishing, where catching the eye of the fish symbolizes gaining prominence.
First Example Sentence: E sa taura na mata ni ika o Jone ena soqo ni matavuvale.
Second Example Sentence: E dau taura na mata ni ika o koya ena gauna ni veitalanoa.
Third Example Sentence: Na nona vosa vakalailai e sa taura na mata ni ika ena bose.

Idiom (Fijian): Sa la'ki gunu wai ni vatu
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone has died or passed away.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Linked to ancient belief of drinking from the sacred stone waters of the spirit world.
First Example Sentence: Era tukuna ni sa la'ki gunu wai ni vatu o koya ena bogi sa oti.
Second Example Sentence: E dua tale na turaga levu sa la'ki gunu wai ni vatu.
Third Example Sentence: Na wati i Pita sa la'ki gunu wai ni vatu ni bera ni siga.

Idiom (Fijian): E dua na domo ga e rogo
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Something is rumored or talked about widely.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to how news spreads in villages by word of mouth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Fijian): /e ndu.a na ðo.mo ŋa e ro.ŋo/
First Example Sentence: E dua na domo ga e rogo me baleti koya ena koro.
Second Example Sentence: E dua na domo ga e rogo ni sa qai laki vola tale ena vuli.
Third Example Sentence: E dua na domo ga e rogo me baleta na kena veisau ena matanitu.

Idiom (Fijian): E sega ni tuki wale na davui
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Warnings or signals have real reasons.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: There’s always a reason behind a warning.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Comes from the conch horn tradition used to signal danger or gatherings.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Fijian): /e se.ŋa ni tu.ki wa.le na nda.βu.i/
First Example Sentence: E sega ni tuki wale na davui ni sa qai tukuni mai vei ira na turaga.
Second Example Sentence: E tukuna na qase ni e sega ni tuki wale na davui ni yaco e dua na leqa.
Third Example Sentence: Na veika e yaco oqo e sega ni tuki wale na davui.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects Fijian chiefly concept of 'i ukuuku' (honor).
First Example Sentence: E vauca na i ukuuku o koya me cakava vakavinaka na nona itavi.
Second Example Sentence: Era dau cakacaka vakaukauwa na turaga ni koro ni e vauca na i ukuuku.
Third Example Sentence: Na nona vakarau e vakaraitaka ni e vauca na i ukuuku.

Idiom (Fijian): Sa dromu na waqa ni vakanuinui
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Drawn from seafaring imagery; loss of hope when a canoe sinks.
First Example Sentence: Ni sa sega ni rawa me bula tale, sa dromu na waqa ni vakanuinui.
Second Example Sentence: Era tukuna na lewe ni koro ni sa dromu na waqa ni vakanuinui.
Third Example Sentence: E dua na gauna dredre ni sa dromu na waqa ni vakanuinui.

Idiom (Fijian): E sa qai rogo na domo ni tagi
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Trouble or grief has become public.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Everyone now knows about the sadness.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Based on communal mourning traditions where grief is expressed openly.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Fijian): /e sa qai ro.ŋo na ðo.mo ni ta.ŋi/
First Example Sentence: E sa qai rogo na domo ni tagi ena koro taucoko.
Second Example Sentence: Ni sa yali o Jone, e sa qai rogo na domo ni tagi.
Third Example Sentence: E sa qai rogo na domo ni tagi ni mate na qase levu.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A sign of misfortune or bad omen.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Something bad is about to happen.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional belief that animal cries predict events.
First Example Sentence: Era kaya na qase ni sa tagi na manumanu ni bera ni yaco e dua na ka ca.
Second Example Sentence: Sa tagi na manumanu ena bogi, ka ra rere kina na gone.
Third Example Sentence: E dau tukuna o tinaqu ni sa tagi na manumanu e dua na ka e yaco.

Idiom (Fijian): E vaka na ika ena wai
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Feeling completely at ease or in one's element.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Based on the Fijian love of the sea and familiarity with water.
First Example Sentence: Ni sa lesu tale ki nona vanua, e vaka na ika ena wai.
Second Example Sentence: E vaka na ika ena wai o Mere ni sa vosa vakalevu ena bose.
Third Example Sentence: E vaka na ika ena wai o koya ena nona cakacaka vou.
